transport.comment:
Yeah, I'm also looking at a motorcycle myself for longer range commuting, but was thinking more along the lines of an NC700x, because it's got crazy good mileage, something like [65mpg (with some people getting as high as 75mpg)](http://www.fuelly.com/motorcycle/honda/nc700x)

If $10k is outside of your price range, I recommend that you hold off for a while, save up, do your research, and figure out exactly what you're going to do.  In the mean time, battery prices are expected to continue to drop as production increases (Gigafactory?) and/or technology improves.   If battery pricing continues the way it has for the past few years, you're looking at a drop of a few thousand dollars over the next few years.

And if you do the tour of the country, hit me up if/when you swing through the Seattle area.

transport.comment: There is much less of a need for a crumple zone in the back. For example let's say your going 50mph, if you had either a front crash into a stationary object or a head on collision the car will literally go from 50mph to 0 in a fraction of a second. The crumple zone spreads the force over a greater amount of time to help reduce the violent stopping effect of the seat belts and air bags as your body continues moving forward after impact and you head and limbs are forcefully whipped forward. However if you were struck from behind by a car or truck going 50 you will almost never go from 0 to 50mph due to the weight of the Tesla. The force of the collision will be much less than a frontal crash and even be less than that if whatever hits you has its own crumple zone. Lastly in a rear impact this force is not being pushed against your body on two small seatbelt straps and an airbag, but it is pushing your body back into a large seat which will cradle your body and head perfectly to reduce injury, especially head and neck injury.

transport.comment:
8 250W solar panels laid out side by side would be about 6 feet wide and about 25 feet long. If the panels were ideally tilted for the sunlight, you could probably dump 1500W back into the battery.

The panels, racking, and cabling would likely weigh around 600 pounds. A 25 foot 10 canoe trailer weighs around 700 pounds, probably pretty close to what we'd need here.

A 3300 pound Nissan LEAF uses about 250 Wh/mile at 55 mph on level ground, or about 14 kW. Add a 1300 pound 25 foot trailer behind the LEAF, and the power draw would probably increase by at least 40% (to 20 kW).

This solar trailer would use 4 times as much power as it was giving back to the EV on the road!

After an hour of driving, the trailer would use an extra 4500 Wh from the LEAF battery. After 3 hours stopped at rest, it would be back to net zero and would start adding net charge to the LEAF. It'd take another 10 ish hours to fully charge the LEAF from its hour of driving, ignoring the fact that the sun is probably down by this time.

Not very good!

How to improve?

One way would be to slow down. At 40 mph, the LEAF without a trailer would only use about 8 kW. The same 40% penalty is now only twice as large as the gain from solar; after driving an hour and a half to cover 60 miles, the LEAF would need to stop for about 10 hours to charge back up (vs the 13 hours at 55 mph).

At even slower speeds - say 20 mph - the panels would start to produce more power than they used. At 10 mph, the panels could almost produce enough energy to drive both the car and the panel trailer.

Another way would be to ditch the trailer, and carry the panels in the car. The same 8 panels carried in the car would take up most of the cargo volume and payload capacity (not sure they'd even fit), but it would only impart a small penalty to highway power consumption (+10%). After 60 miles of driving at 40 mph and pulling the panels out, the car would fully charge in about 9 hours at the destination.

Another way would be to build an integrated aero tail for the LEAF and cover the roof and tail with solar cells; probably 1+ kW could be fitted. The solar tail would add some weight - say 200 pounds. The solar tail would really only help at higher speeds, say 25% reduction in power draw at 40 mph (12% from improved aero, 12% from solar power) and about 25% at 55 mph (18% from improved aero, 7% from solar generated). At 70 mph the majority of the power reduction would be from aero, still about 25% overall (20% aero, 4% solar power).

The 1 kW tail would still take quite a while to charge the car even in ideal conditions: 1.5 hours of driving at 40 mph would take 9 hours to charge; 1 hour of driving at 55 mph would take about 10 hours to charge, and an hour of driving at 70 mph would take about 18 hours to charge.

To do much better than this you will need a much lighter, more aerodynamic vehicle.

transport.comment:
Time for some real numbers :)
I stayed up till 1am last night so I could watch this presention.  I am a Musk fanboy.  That said.....  We need to learn more about this battery system.  At first glance from the specs online his system is more form than function.  Here is why:
My home usage is about 30kWh a day.  Since you don't want a battery dropping below 50% average a day then you need about 60kWh capacity.  A Trojan L-16RE-B battery would take 3 strings of 8 batteries to get to 60kWh .  Total cost would be about $9438 at last nights price online.
Tesla will have two models.  A (100Hr) 10kWh backup system for $3500 that isn't designed to be drawn down every day.  A (20Hr) 7kWh system for $3000 that is designed to be used daily.  **IF** that is total capacity and **IF** we can only use 50% of that on a daily draw then you would end up needing the max 9 units which would cost you $25,800.
The Tesla system does not come with the DC-AC inverter so if you don't have an existing solar system be prepared to spend several more thousands.  Lets assume though that if your looking at this that you do have the inverters and they are smart enough to run this system.

Trojan system would cost you $9,438
Tesla system would cost you $25,800
So you would be spending $16,362 extra to have a pretty wall mounted setup.  

Until the end of 2016 we get tax rebates that equal about 50% if you add the battery system as part of a solar install.
So the Trojan system will end up costing $4,719 as apposed to $12,900.

I'm using Trojan as just an example.  A high end rolls S-530 setup would cost you $10,598 for the same 3 string 60 kWh system.

I'm hoping that the Tesla kWh figure is actually the 50% usage number.  That will make it much closer and form may be worth the extra cost.  Will be interesting to see how this battery is actually tested in comparison.  I know Elon says current batteries suck but his battery is still Li-Ion based.  There is a lot of really cool battery technology that is being tested that should come out within the next 2-5 years that will see these numbers change drastically and could see costs drop over 70% by the end of the decade.  Especially if Graphin turns out as good as it looks. 

This all said I hope that lots of people buy just one of these batteries from Tesla so that advances in research and the influx of other companies create an environment that finally pushes solar power of the top of the hill.  These systems are already cheaper than the power company for most areas.  But if they get another 25% cheaper or even better we will see wide spread adoption.  The planet smiled a little bit last night.

I own an Energi vehicle and it absolutely can charge while running the A/C. I haven't had it weather that needed the heat, but I've definitely sat in the cold A/C while it charged. 

"Too fast" in the Energi is 85 MPH. Around here (and most of America) that'd be quite the heavy ticket going faster than that. I don't think anybody ever wanted to race their C-Max on the track. 

I'm pretty satisfied with my C-Max Energi, averaging 29 miles per charge, far better than the EPA estimate would have suggested. 

It was *significantly* cheaper than the Volt ($21,415 after the tax credit and incentive) - the Volt would have been $26k ish (after tax credit, no dealer near me was willing to deal on price).

transport.comment:
Maybe, but we need a great deal more information to know for sure. For example, what's your daily mileage? Where exactly do you live/work? Maybe there's a fast charger near your home/work that you could use every couple of days. Or if your drive is short enough compared to your battery range, a level 2 charge just on the weekend might be enough.

But as a broad generalization, if you can't charge at home or at work or anywhere nearby, then you probably shouldn't buy an electric car just yet. transport.comment:
Horses for courses. I happen to really like the i3 - certainly enough to go and buy it. Range wise, I'm planning to go to France this summer, and back; in part to prove it's easy (the other part is cost! Petrol is expensive in Europe) and that Range Anxiety is as the article suggests, just a pointless worry.
 
Back to your reply: The trade off right now is battery capacity vs weight vs range. Increased capacity means increased range, but increased weight; which in turn decreases range. The technology is improving all the time, with the 94Ah i3 due to be replaced by a 120Ah (mine for reference is a 60Ah). Every car manufacturer is working on electric-hybrid right now, and with the UK clarifying its position on BEV only post 2040, and other Euro countries set to follow suit, chances are many of them will slow even on the Hybrids. 
 
Right now, your wish list is, as you say, not really achievable. But with Ford and VW getting in on the act, it's a long way to being fulfilled.

transport.comment:
The public still sees EVs in basically two ways. 

First, there are people who are almost entirely looking for cost savings. The interest comes from not spending on gasoline, maintenance, etc. Often, this customer is cross shopping an ev with a civic or corolla to see what will cost less in total over their time of ownership. This crowd generally looks at bolts, e golf's, leafs, etc. 

Second, there are people who are looking for cachet. They want the "cool" factor and are willing to pay more than they would for an ice vehicle to get it. This crowd generally looks at teslas, taycans, I paces, etc.

Of course this is simplifying it a bit, but from a primary reason for buying perspective this grabs almost every current ev buyer. 

The problem for oems is that the first group is almost by definition less profitable. When you're comparing dollars saved on a spreadsheet, you'll be cutthroat in your shopping. If a bolt is 200 less than a leaf, almost the entirely of this market will go to the bolt. If the leaf becomes cheaper, it will dominate. This market will always squeeze profits down to the absolute minimum. Even worse, for an oem, these same customers are likely to hold their cars for a decade or more. Limiting potential future sales, and requiring a better built car overall or risk having this customer jump ship when stuff starts to break at year 5.

The second group will more often go for a specific car because they want that one car, even if the costs are higher. This customer will live with lower build quality because they wanted a different feature instead (speed, looks, branding). This customer is also significantly more likely to lease or turn over cars every few years, increasing selling opportunities. They are also more likely to pay for expensive (and profitable) options. 

If you're an OEM looking at this, it's pretty clear which option is more profitable. GM focusing on the later makes a lot of sense from a business perspective. Until the ev market is large enough that making a very small amount on a lot of cars is feasible, associating your ev with existing high end branding just makes sense.

Ioniq 6 is more comparable to the Model 3 (Ioniq 5 is priced competitive to the Y though)

The Ioniq 6 has a $5000 cash offer on it, or a $7500 lease bonus, or 1.49% financing. 

Tesla lists their prices without the $1390 destination fee or their bizarre order fee, and by default includes the possible tax credit and "fuel savings" to make it look cheaper than it is. The cheapest "inventory" Model 3 is $39,420 with destination, and the cheapest Ioniq 6 is $37,715 with the cash offer and destination. The Model 3 will get the tax credit, Ioniq 6 cheaper insurance and a better warranty.  It looks better with the lease deal for the Ioniq, which shows $401 / month with $5008 due at signing for the 3 year 10,000 mile lease. The inventory Model 3 shows $399 per month with $5594 due at signing for their 3 year 10,000 mile lease.

The comparison between the Model 3 Long Range and the Ioniq 6 SE with the longer range is even better for the Hyundai, even without getting a tax credit.

It's also less than accurate saying they're all collecting dust. The SE Long Range is still hard to get, and the rest still don't have out of the norm time in inventory.

housing.comment:
First thing you're gonna want is some solar panels.   I have one of the Harbor Freight kits (not really worth it) and I have a 100 watt 12v panel from WindyNation. *Totaling 145 watts) I know WindyNation has a 200 watt kit on sale right now with 2 100 watt panels, charge controller, mount brackets and I think some cabling + 25 year warranty on the panels for 279 with free shipping.

Then you'll want a charge controller.  I have a cheap 30 amp charge controller that I got by looking on Amazon.  It's basically the cheapest one from China.   The important part about the charge controller is that it has a DC output on it.  Mine does what the documentation calls "street light mode"   By this, it will activate the 12v output when there is no longer voltage coming from the panels.  I'll get to how I have it set up in a bit.

You'll want a battery or more.  I use 2 group 24 Marine/RV 12 volt batteries from Wal-Mart currently. Probably pick up more when I get more panels.

And an inverter.  You'll probably want something in the range of 3000 running watts, so you'll be putting down some money on this.    You'll also need some pretty healthy wiring for that.  As you'll be talking ability to put around 200 amps to the DC side.  I have a 1200 watt MSW inverter that won't start my 10 amp circular saw, so you need to have more inverter than what you're planning on pulling.  

Pure sine wave is the preferred inverter, though more expensive.  The Modified Sine Wave, like I have, doesn't do the best with inductive loads like electric motors.  The motor will tend to buzz, and run a bit slower and less efficient.  But they do work.

With my Harbor Freight solar kit I got 2 12vdc 5 watt CFL's with it.  I use them for outdoor lighting. (Though, I haven't had the CFL try to light during the cold winter months yet so I'll find out here in about January if they work when really cold).   These bulbs, which might just be on a adapter base, have a regular medium screw in base like a household light bulb does.   So, they're screwed into an exterior light fixture.  The other end is wired to the DC output on the charge controller. The controller is set to street light mode for 2 hours (which is adjustable from always off any number of hours, dusk til dawn, always on, or selectable).  So after the sun goes down, the controller simply draws power from the batteries for the exterior lighting.  

From the sounds of it, you'll probably want to set up something similar.

housing.comment:
I'm in Taiwan and I can get 1cSt silicone oil directly from a shop in Taipei for about eight bucks a liter. I looked on eBay and their prices seem a lot higher than that. For me it's a workable solution at that price. But there are many other heat transfer solutions. Brines are popular as well. 

One consideration you haven't mentioned is pumps. That's a lot more problematic at high temperatures than low temperatures but it is one that I have to admit is quite serious when you're getting into liquid heat transfer solutions. 

You asked about humidity and that's a great point. I already have several Panasonic dehumidifiers in my house so it stays quite dry. I've modified them so that they continuously dump water out to some flower boxes. I avoided them for years assuming that they were electricity hogs but I later learned that they were quite efficient and the ones I have are each about 150watt. I run them 24 hours a day but it's not a huge burden. I have some PV on the roof as well. 

As I was explaining in my original post, I have this big hot solar thermal tank and I have considered using the heat from that to run a dessicant wheel in one of the air conditioning holes in the walls of the house. However, since I got the dehumidifiers I'm not sure if it's really worth the hassle. What I keep coming back to with all these neat solutions is the need for pumps. This is definitely the big gotcha in all of these projects. It's not a deal killer but it's definitely worth considering carefully. It's easy to think it's all simple but the pump issue doesn't solve itself. Just finding pumps can be tricky business and many people who sell them have no idea what their actual specs are and simply say that they're for water or diesel fuel transfer and can't be used for anything else. I've had many pump dealers simply refuse to sell me anything at any price when I started telling them what I was doing. It can be frustrating. I've ended up with some interesting industrial grade solutions from Aliexpress though. The trick is that when you start adding more and more applications you need more and more pumps. It's better to stay focused on the big goals like whole house cooling instead of getting off into say a solar clothes dryer or something of that nature which sounds cool till you realize how complex and costly all the pumping and heat exchange equipment is.  

I also can't get net metering although I do use a grid tie inverter and some panels to offset some of my usage. I have no agreement with the utility on that though and net metering is not an option. They haven't complained about what I'm doing so far but I never asked them for any permission. I used a very cheap grid-tie inverter off of Aliexpress that only ran me eighty bucks. It's rated for 1000 watts and I run two 250 watt panels into it. For me the PV partly offsets things like my dehumidifiers but they really don't draw much current. I highly recommend dehumidifiers as a first approach because it blew me away how much it improved the interior air quality of my house when I got one and then I wanted another one because it was such a nice improvement. We used to really struggle with mold and dampness and those days are gone. 

Also, you might find this helpful when considering the economics of transfer fluid: 

Using 1/2 inch tube it's about one US gallon per hundred feet of tube. So at four liters per gallon and eight bucks a liter that's US$32 per hundred feet of heat exchange tubing to charge it with 1cSt silicone oil with the price I can get here. If you can't get a reasonable price consider going with a brine solution. Naturally you have to take that into account with your pump selection as well.  

You could even use regular table salt but nitrate salts should be cheap too. The reason I like oil as a heat transfer solution is that I believe it will be easier on the pump and the pumps are very much a real-world issue. In the end, if the pump ain't working the whole thing is going nowhere. Again though if you're only targeting cold you've got it way easier than my case where I need high temperature. High temperature pumps suck because you can't use plastic and it's hard to find small metal pumps and then if you do find them they have to be appropriate for the viscosity you're targeting and can't have seals that will be eroded by what you're pumping and all this bullshit. I confess that part sucks. But that's my burden with the snazzy heat-to-cold plan. For this other idea of going with an off the shelf ice source it's much simpler because you should be okay with plastic. Plastic should work for low temperature and even brines should be fine with plastics. You can probably get away with even a cheap pond pump since you don't need high temperatures.

A 16% NaCL brine will enable you to go down to -10C and would be a very cheap and easy to source way to go that would probably work with a cheap plastic pond pump.   

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brine

You could start with that and if you ran into freezing problems (rather unlikely in the hot summer when you'd be using it the most) you could take the plunge and try to source some synthetic low viscosity oils.

250W peltier cooler - $30 - https://www.amazon.com/TEC1-12710-Thermoelectric-Cooler-Peltier-Pinkcoo/dp/B009T0FE7G

housing.comment:
Just keep in mind that using the grid as a battery will only work for a limited number of people. A day will come when there is so much rooftop solar that the utilities will have no way to handle it other than dropping connections to sections of the grid. They will have ramped down all generation and turned on all storage and still there will be too much. 

California is the state that's closest to this becoming an issue. This summer even, PG&E is expecting to need to ramp down some plants that have never had to ramp down before. 

People need to understand that the current situation is not sustainable and that regulated utilities don't make money from the amount of power that they sell. 

They make money by investing in infrastructure and getting a reasonable rate of return on their investment. It's not that they want to crush the rooftop solar competitor, it's just that it's a difficult, expensive problem to deal with that will require more infrastructure which means higher energy cost distributed across fewer customers. Nobody wants that.

housing.comment:
"In other words, utility scale solar drives the cost of utility energy down; while individual rooftop solar drive the cost of utility energy up."

Not exactly. Utility scale solar sees benefits in capital costs because of the scale - buy more get a lower price. But it also tends to add to distribution costs (many solar farms are not ideally located near highest demand). Total net, it is somewhat cheaper per kW and per kWh.

Residential solar is typically all behind the meter. So it theoretically could lower distribution costs (utility or provider costs). Currently one issue preventing residential solar from being almost equally cost effective is the time of day supply/demand reality.  Time shifting or leveling the demand per 24 hour period (demand = what is seen at the meter) is getting more cost effective, but energy storage has a ways to go.

Some who have installed solar on their homes also are diligent in their energy monitoring and management. That can help them save even more.

housing.comment:
I don't think load factor is substantial. I haven't heard of load factors being greater than 15% on commercial facilities, but I really don't know. It would be a great question for /r/electricians.

But again, I don't think load factor is that big of a deal. Just like solar goes through an off-peak and peak cycle, so does most person's electric use. I've found that peak load tracks pretty evenly with installed solar array sizes, although perhaps not in cloudy climates.

In Europe, a common restriction is to make sure the solar array doesn't backfeed more than 4kW. Americans seem to have better interconnection rights than they realize (although, my belief is that the electric grid should be a public asset with extreme consumer protections such as net-metering, RPS, and PURPA enforced at the federal level in addition to a carbon tax).

housing.comment:
Yeah, the "51%" FAO figures that Cowspiracy uses are routinely discredited. Fossil energy is the biggest driver of climate change.

The thing is, how much power does an average consumer have over where their energy comes from?

Consumers could cry to their congressmen, but lord knows that's not going to do any good. Our lawmakers are corrupt and the election system is completely broken.

 If your utility company offers a renewable exchange program, you could opt to pay a few more cents per kwh and they'll promise to buy some solar/wind power, but what if they don't offer one?

 If you're rich and own your own home, you could install solar panels, but a lot of people don't have the means to do that.

You can reduce your energy consumption, but at some point we want lights, electronics, refrigeration, hot food, hot water, and HVAC, and reducing your use doesn't change the source. 

And that's only your personal residential use: everything ever manufactured used energy. You'd have to cut out purchasing most non-essential goods to take a bite out of that.

Energy use is something most people can only make minimal reductions to and have little power over where it comes from. Choosing to avoid animal products is something that everyone^1 has *total* control over. Your congressman, your utility company, the entire consumer products chain, none of them have any power over that. And it requires only minimal material investment, most investment being time spent researching and learning new recipes. 

Going vegan has the biggest return on investment and is the most accessible thing the average person can do to effect climate change. 

^1 Provided you're not under unacommodating institutional or parental care or live in a food desert.

housing.comment:
Why are you acting like there aren't tens of MILLIONS of square miles of land area available. Even if only 1% of that land is usable and you cover it in solar panels, you would still produce more power than humanity would ever consume. In fact, it would only take a 10,000 square mile array in the middle of the god-forsaken desert somewhere to completely replace the entire source of power for the USA (http://www.terrawatts.com/PV-production.html). 

Now that we have established there is FAR more land area available than could ever conceivably be needed, why on Earth would you want to put fragile solar panels in the dang road? The venn diagram of things a road does and things a solar panel does has just about no overlap whatsoever. Solar roadways are one of those things that appeal to the scientifically illiterate because at first glance, we have lots of roads sittin around doin' nothin' all day, why not slap solar panels all over them? Putting solar panels in the road can certainly be done but why would you want to put something that needs as much sun exposure as possible in a place where it won't be pointed at the sun any other time besides noon and where cars will be driving over and shading the panels? Putting solar panels under civic areas and where people live means they won't get any sun. It makes soooo much more sense to put solar panels on buildings or in large solar farms where their positioning and maintenance can be optimized for peak power production. Getting power to where it needs to be is not a problem that needs solved in most of the world. The electrical distribution grid is already pretty much in place where it needs to be.

housing.comment:
Imagining an ideal solution where the car is at 50% battery, I can charge it to full in a day. 

As for cost effectiveness: my power mains supplies the entire compound, which is my family and 2 other family units. All in all, there's 8 people using this cabinet. Our power bill is an average of 200€ a month. AFTER we put in the solar panels, the 1st power bill that came back was 160€, and the one after that was 163€. Granted, we're also working from home due to Covid, but even the first 3 months of the quarantine, we were still paying around 200€.

The savings aren't stellar, but they're enough that I don't regret putting the system in. My estimations put me at saving about 800€ a year, which means, that In 5 years, I'll have paid the whole thing and then some. This estimation already takes the lull in production due to winter. 

Please bear in mind that I installed a larger inverter because I have tri-phasic power, and I want to add more panels later down the line. If you don't have those requirements, you can get a much cheaper install than I did.   


This might help you in your quest: [https://pvwatts.nrel.gov/](https://pvwatts.nrel.gov/)

housing.comment:
I'm not sure what you mean by that, sorry. But I think I haven't explained this well - this was meant to be a subjective question, not a calculation. If the goal is to get the lowest utility bill, then the answer must be theory #2: charge the car when rates are lowest (unless I'm totally bonkers). But if the goal is less about saving money, and more about saving the planet, is theory #1 a greener alternative? Or does it not matter? 

Theory #1 ensures that all the energy needed for the car comes from your solar panels, so nothing is drawn from the grid and the utility doesn't need to burn any fossil fuel on your behalf when you charge the car. But theory #2 may also offset somebody else's energy use during the day, when you're selling energy to the grid, so the utility doesn't need to burn any fossil fuel on that other person's behalf.

Basically the question is whether you're doing more to save the planet by eating your own electrons, vs selling them to the grid and buying them back later with net metering.

housing.comment:
Topping the list of things that seemed like a good idea at the time sits wind and solar power.

What, with the energy sources that drive them free and natural; with no visible emissions of spent gas or fumes; with their shiny panels harvesting the sun’s rays and delivering electricity for five or six hours a day (rain and cloud cover permitting); with their majestic 50-60m blades lovingly caressing benevolent breezes and thereby ‘powering’ hundreds of thousands of homes (around-the-clock, according to wind industry marketing blurb), why wouldn’t the gullible masses be sucked into the belief that sunshine and breezes will soon deliver all of our energy needs, forevermore?

That was then. This is now.

The increasing reliance on the unreliables has been revealed for what it is: sheer lunacy.

But this is stupidity with a kicker: the blackouts caused by sudden and unpredictable collapses in wind and solar output kill people. Especially in the northern hemisphere during bitter, freezing weather. Just ask relatives of the hundreds of Texans who died last February during its Big Freeze.

housing.comment:
I don't have any stake in this, but I hate to see people get screwed over when it comes to solar.  It's like if I knew you were about to ask out a crazy girl.  I can tell you she's psycho and she'll screw up your house and finances, but I can't stop you from dating her.

Before you agree to anything with Vivint, at least ask to see:

1. The billing history.

2. The system production history from the equipment, not from Vivint.    This generally comes from the inverters.  I usually see EnPhase and their Enlighten monitoring.   I've found that Vivint is extremely reluctant to share this information, even though it should be very easy to access.  

These two sets of numbers should match.

Vivint's solar contract doesn't hold them accountable for much.  There's zero guarantee of how much power the system will produce. 
 Generally, if the system stops working, they are extremely slow to respond (if at all).  From what I've seen, they will simply keep billing customers, even if they can't prove the system is making power.  

I don't know your specific market, what utility you have, or the specific production of your system, but I'd be very surprised if a new 4.5 kw system would cost you any more than $13k (after the 30% federal tax credit).  If your lease payment is $100/month, and the escalator is only 2.9%, you'll pay about $24,000 to Vivint in the next 14 years.

In my area, net metering is also grandfathered.  It's based on approval size, not any specific system.  If one of my clients wanted to replace a 4.5 kw system with another 4.5 kw system, they could keep their existing net metering agreement.

I will agree that replacing an existing PV system is fairly extreme, but that's the level of problems I've seen people have with their Vivint systems.  If it is working, and you (or the current homeowner) are able to buy it out and get Vivint out of your life, that's still a better option than taking over the lease.  

Again, I strongly urge you to check out the comments and reviews before agreeing to anything. You don't want to spend the next 14 years shackled to this company.

food.comment:
The fact is, many people have no interest or desire to ever stop or even slow down their animal consumption. It would most likely be a matter of several generations to get the world to even be a majority vegan. I probably wouldn't personally eat it, just because meat grosses me out now, but wouldn't really have a problem with it from an exploitation standpoint.

I agree my diabetic analogy was flawed, and the makeup one is better. You say "those ingredients aren't themselves from animals", which is the exact situation this lab meat is. It would be an almost exact replica of meat, but still would not come from animals (beyond the very beginning stages). I don't see how lab meat encourages the notion that animal exploitation is OK unless people are not told it is lab meat.

I would be perfectly OK with taking cells from a willing human to grow for human meat (though I doubt it would be a hit). I am against both slavery and animal exploitation, but I think if you asked a slave to give up some cells to free all of the slaves of the world, he/she would probably agree to it. Unfortunately, animals cannot consent, so we must make this choice for them. Just as we have chosen to exploit them now, we must make the choice to stop exploiting them. I feel that lab meet would be a more practical answer to this in many people's cases who have no interest in cutting down their meat production.

food.comment:
Everyone is different, so there really isn't one best way to ease your transition.

For me, I've found that understanding the true extent of animal sufferings is the best way to stay on veganism. 

A good, short video is "Meet Your Meat":  http://youtu.be/32IDVdgmzKA

"Earthlings" is a full-length film you can watch for free: http://earthlings.com/?page_id=32

Here's a great, short talk by an activist: http://youtu.be/uQCe4qEexjc

> The hardest things for me to stay away from are dairy products. I love cheese.

This may or may not work for everyone, but I've known someone who fights off temptations to eat cheese by looking at pictures like this:

http://imgur.com/0soXx

and ask herself *"Do I want to support this?"*

> In an area where I don't have a Whole Foods or Trader Joe's.. is Publix my best option? What are some ideas for vegan lunches that are easy for a thirty minute work break? 

You really don't need Whole Foods or Trader Joe's to be vegan. I never go to Whole Foods and go to Trader Joe's mostly just for treats. 

I usually make a pot of steamed brown rice and a pot of veggie/beans/tofu stew. I put them in the fridge/freezer and reheat with microwave. That lasts for days, very easy and time-saving. 

Good luck.

food.comment:
> vegans care more about animals than the immigrants that pick their vegetables

That's not true... I'll explain why.

It's easy to avoid animal products since all food is legally required to have an ingredients list on it.  I can pick something up, see if it's vegan or not in about 10 seconds.

There are no labels showing farm worker conditions.  It's virtually impossible to know where/how a particular piece of produce or ingredient of food was produced and what the conditions are like on that farm for workers.

I think one of the main reasons why they're treated so bad is because employers know that they can... the workers are illegal so if they complain, they'll be deported.  

I care about migrant workers and I'd love to have our government institute a REAL guest worker program that brings them out of the shadows and legalizes their status, gives them a path to citizenship and/or amnesty.

If we legalized the workers, they'd have a lot more recourse to complain about unsafe working conditions, challenge illegally low wages, and collect workers comp if they're injured.

I support political candidates that have a similar stance on immigration & reform of the current system... not sure what else I can do.

food.comment: From what I've read, our digestive tract is the appropriate length for an omnivore, but not a carnivore or herbivore; it's between the two in length. The digestive tract thing is only really a concern when we're talking about how calorically dense our food is. Carnivores need very short tracts because their food is calorie-dense and relatively simple to extract nutrition from. Herbivores (eating mostly leafy plants) need longer tracts to extract as much sustenance as possible and work through the fiber. Even though vegans eat plant-based diets, the omnivore-length digestive tract is perfectly sufficient for us because we are eating a variety of nutrient-dense food in addition to leafy low-calorie food.

food.comment:
Vegan diet != magic!

Do your research on causes of certain things and if there even is a possible connection with diet.

The two main reasons why vegans tend to get sick less often, as far as I know are:

1. Dramatically reduced intake of endotoxins. Endotoxins are parts of dead bacteria. If they get into the bloodstream, it triggers an immune-reaction and thus binds capacities of your immune-system that it otherwise could use to fight an actual infection. Endotoxins are mostly found in meat.

2. More protective gut-flora. The insides of your bowels are covered by a layer of mucus formed by gut-bacteria. What the composition of those is greatly depends on what you eat. The "good ones" thrive on fiber. If there's a lot of them, they protect against endotoxins as well as real threats.

Being vegan, while always reducing your endotoxin-intake, does not necessarily mean you'll have a lot of fiber in your diet. Processed food has very little of that. So that's a thing you might have done "wrong".

Also keep in mind that a reduced likeliness of getting sick doesn't mean you are immune!

food.comment:
During the pandemic our Uncle Vic lost close to 60 pounds on a meat and keto diet and was finally able to ski again and even started to look like he had abs. He felt great and kept talking about his energy levels. We were really proud of him for losing all of that weight and he bragged about how it was "all bullet-proof coffee and beef". He kept saying that "it's the carbs that will kill you". Then after a long weekend skiing he took a nap and died in his sleep on the couch of a massive heart attack at the age 62 nearly twenty years younger than both his parents were when they died. We had him tested for Covid thinking that might be the cause, but it turned out it was multiple blocked arteries and a massive heart attack.

I lost a bunch of weight on meat-keto a few years back so I know that it works to lose belly fat and does help you get lean. But I had weird health issues that made me drop the meat and later on the milk products too. Part of the problem is that the way keto people talk, it's like they just look in the mirror and see the real weight loss, haven't had that before, and immediately dismiss stories that don't support the lifestyle they want. I see comments like "they're lying" and then attribute anything vegan as being connected to "an agenda". For some it is. For me and many others it just isn't.

Vic was a decent, genuine guy and we're happy he got to do something he loved for a few months before he passed. We all know someone that's keto. It's not going to lead to death in everyone or probably even most that use meat-based keto to lose some weight but filling your body full of large quantities of saturated fat so regularly causes health issues and sometimes death.

food.comment:
I think there are many known reasons why people go Vegan (the only true one being a belief in animal rights let's put that aside for now).

There the:

Animal Rights Vegan: Someone who believes that animals should be given rights and treated with basic respect.

Environmental Vegan: People who believe that plant based dieting is best for environment.

Health Vegan: People who believe that a plant based diet is better for their health.

and a much less well known one due to the structure that our society follows.

The Social Vegan: People who believe that there is social credit to be gained from being Vegan. I would argue that most celebrities who go Vegan and then flip flop are social vegans. But also you can imagine an entirely Vegan world where most people are vegan not because they believe in animal rights but because it's socially expected that they are vegan. I think most Carnists are at their core social carnists.

These ""vegans"" gain the same amount of social credit from just telling people they're vegan/vegetarian regardless of their actual actions. Therefor they don't necessarily have qualms with eating animals and then calling themselves vegan for the social credit anyway. It's rare because a lot of people don't see much social credit to be gained from being vegan/vegetarian.

food.comment:
Sure can do ! :)

~2 cups + a little more of shredded cabbage
1 large carrot
1 small red onion
1/2 cup oat fraiche (a plant-based creme fraiche)
1/2 cup vegan mayo
2 tsp dijon mustard
1 tsp coconut sugar (use ordinary sugar if you want, or some other sweetener, or skip it)
salt and pepper!

Just shred the cabbage and the carrots, and finely slice the red onion. The mix everything together (be careful not to use too much dijon, or a too powerful one. Add it as you taste the coleslaw)! BAM! 
Let it sit for ~30 minutes, and devour!

food.comment: You can't turn someone vegan; they have to do it of their own volition. Even with a flawless argument, no one is obligated to change because you said so (unfortunately for the animals). :'( Ease off on the arguing/convincing and just live your life as a good example. Show her how healthy and delicious plant-based food can be. Be knowledgeable but amicable with answering questions and providing information. I've found that the more you "force" people, the more they get angry, defensive, and set in their ways. Strive to make people feel good about every positive choice they make, not guilty for being anything less than 100% vegan. Good luck!
